description.narrative: In January 2018, the number of people returning to their area of origin has surpassed the number of people displaced in Iraq, for the first time since the beginning of the Iraq crisis in December 2013. As of end of August 2019, the number of internally displaced persons (IDPs) across Iraq has decreased to 1.5 million, and the number of returnees has increased to more than 4.35 million, according to IOM Iraq’s latest Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) report. Despite the increase in the number of returnees, the pace of return is slowing down as the remaining IDPs face obstacles to return.While obstacles to return vary depending on the region, destruction and/or damage to houses and the lack of employment and/or livelihood opportunities in location of origin are among common obstacles that are reported. It is also to be noted that those in protracted displacement are often the most vulnerable, such as female-headed households. Urgent support is needed to facilitate voluntary, dignified and sustainable returns of vulnerable displaced persons through comprehensive support that provides adequate housing and employment/livelihood opportunities.
